answer:
<p>No, you can't use <code>mysql</code> and <code>mysqli</code> together.  They are separate APIs and the resources they create are incompatible with one another.</p>

<p>There is a <code>mysqli_close</code>, though.</p>

<p>Technically you can use as many separate connections as you want, while your problem is caused by a mere typo - you only cannot use resources from one extension with functions from another, which is quite obviously.</p>

<p>However, you <strong>should avoid multiple connections from the same script</strong>, no matter from single API or different ones. As it will burden your database server and exhaust its resources. So, although technically you can, you shouldn't mix different extensions in your code, save for the short period of refactoring.</p>

<p><code>MySQLi</code> is a lot more secure than <code>MySQL</code> which is anyway now deprecated. That's why you should stick with <code>MySQLi</code> and also you can't mix them as they are both different.</p>
